description:
## Description:

`gg` is V's simple graphics module. It is currently implemented using `sokol`, and makes easy creating apps that just need a way to draw simple 2D shapes, and to react to user's keyboard/mouse input.

## Example:


```v cgen
module main

import gg
import gx

fn main() {
mut context := gg.new_context(
bg_color: gx.rgb(174, 198, 255)
width: 600
height: 400
window_title: 'Polygons'
frame_fn: frame
)
context.run()
}

fn frame(mut ctx gg.Context) {
ctx.begin()
ctx.draw_convex_poly([f32(100.0), 100.0, 200.0, 100.0, 300.0, 200.0, 200.0, 300.0, 100.0, 300.0],
gx.blue)
ctx.draw_poly_empty([f32(50.0), 50.0, 70.0, 60.0, 90.0, 80.0, 70.0, 110.0], gx.black)
ctx.draw_triangle_filled(450, 142, 530, 280, 370, 280, gx.red)
ctx.end()
}
```

comments.text:  begin prepares the context for drawing.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) begin()
children.name: begin

comments.text:  cache_image caches the image `img` in memory for later reuse.
 cache_image returns the cache index of the cached image.
 See also: get_cached_image_by_idx
 See also: remove_cached_image_by_idx

children.content: fn (mut ctx Context) cache_image(img Image) int
children.name: cache_image

comments.text:  create_image creates an `Image` from `file`.

children.content: fn (mut ctx Context) create_image(file string) !Image
children.name: create_image

comments.text:  create_image_from_byte_array creates an `Image` from the
 byte array `b`.
 See also: create_image_from_memory

children.content: fn (mut ctx Context) create_image_from_byte_array(b []u8) !Image
children.name: create_image_from_byte_array

comments.text:  create_image_from_memory creates an `Image` from the
 memory buffer `buf` of size `bufsize`.
 See also: create_image_from_byte_array

children.content: fn (mut ctx Context) create_image_from_memory(buf &u8, bufsize int) !Image
children.name: create_image_from_memory

comments.text:  create_image_with_size creates an `Image` from `file` in the given
 `width` x `height` dimension.
 TODO copypasta

children.content: fn (mut ctx Context) create_image_with_size(file string, width int, height int) Image
children.name: create_image_with_size

comments.text:  draw_arc_empty draws the outline of an arc.
 `x`,`y` defines the end point of the arc (center of the circle that the arc is part of).
 `inner_radius` defines the radius of the arc (length from the center point where the arc is drawn).
 `thickness` defines how wide the arc is drawn.
 `start_angle` is the angle in radians at which the arc starts.
 `end_angle` is the angle in radians at which the arc ends.
 `segments` affects how smooth/round the arc is.
 `c` is the color of the arc outline.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_arc_empty(x f32, y f32, inner_radius f32, thickness f32, start_angle f32, end_angle f32, segments int, c gx.Color)
children.name: draw_arc_empty

comments.text:  draw_arc_filled draws a filled arc.
 `x`,`y` defines the central point of the arc (center of the circle that the arc is part of).
 `inner_radius` defines the radius of the arc (length from the center point where the arc is drawn).
 `thickness` defines how wide the arc is drawn.
 `start_angle` is the angle in radians at which the arc starts.
 `end_angle` is the angle in radians at which the arc ends.
 `segments` affects how smooth/round the arc is.
 `c` is the fill color of the arc.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_arc_filled(x f32, y f32, inner_radius f32, thickness f32, start_angle f32, end_angle f32, segments int, c gx.Color)
children.name: draw_arc_filled

comments.text:  draw_arc_line draws a line arc.
 `x`,`y` defines the end point of the arc (center of the circle that the arc is part of).
 `radius` defines the radius of the arc (length from the center point where the arc is drawn).
 `start_angle` is the angle in radians at which the arc starts.
 `end_angle` is the angle in radians at which the arc ends.
 `segments` affects how smooth/round the arc is.
 `c` is the color of the arc/outline.

children.content: fn (ctx Context) draw_arc_line(x f32, y f32, radius f32, start_angle f32, end_angle f32, segments int, c gx.Color)
children.name: draw_arc_line

comments.text:  draw_circle_empty draws the outline of a circle.
 `x`,`y` defines the center of the circle.
 `radius` defines the radius of the circle.
 `c` is the color of the outline.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_circle_empty(x f32, y f32, radius f32, c gx.Color)
children.name: draw_circle_empty

comments.text:  draw_circle_filled draws a filled circle.
 `x`,`y` defines the center of the circle.
 `radius` defines the radius of the circle.
 `c` is the fill color.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_circle_filled(x f32, y f32, radius f32, c gx.Color)
children.name: draw_circle_filled

comments.text:  draw_circle_line draws the outline of a circle with a specific number of segments.
 `x`,`y` defines the center of the circle.
 `radius` defines the radius of the circle.
 `segments` affects how smooth/round the circle is.
 `c` is the color of the outline.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_circle_line(x f32, y f32, radius int, segments int, c gx.Color)
children.name: draw_circle_line

comments.text:  draw_circle_with_segments draws a filled circle with a specific number of segments.
 `x`,`y` defines the center of the circle.
 `radius` defines the radius of the circle.
 `segments` affects how smooth/round the circle is.
 `c` is the fill color.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_circle_with_segments(x f32, y f32, radius f32, segments int, c gx.Color)
children.name: draw_circle_with_segments

comments.text:  draw_convex_poly draws a convex polygon, given an array of points, and a color.
 NOTE that the points must be given in clockwise winding order.
 The contents of the `points` array should be `x` and `y` coordinate pairs.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_convex_poly(points []f32, c gx.Color)
children.name: draw_convex_poly

comments.text:  draw_cubic_bezier draws a cubic Bézier curve, also known as a spline, from four points.
 The four points is provided as one `points` array which contains a stream of point pairs (x and y coordinates).
 Thus a cubic Bézier could be declared as: `points := [x1, y1, control_x1, control_y1, control_x2, control_y2, x2, y2]`.
 Please see `draw_cubic_bezier_in_steps` to control the amount of steps (segments) used to draw the curve.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_cubic_bezier(points []f32, c gx.Color)
children.name: draw_cubic_bezier

comments.text:  draw_cubic_bezier_in_steps draws a cubic Bézier curve, also known as a spline, from four points.
 The smoothness of the curve can be controlled with the `steps` parameter. `steps` determines how many iterations is
 taken to draw the curve.
 The four points is provided as one `points` array which contains a stream of point pairs (x and y coordinates).
 Thus a cubic Bézier could be declared as: `points := [x1, y1, control_x1, control_y1, control_x2, control_y2, x2, y2]`.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_cubic_bezier_in_steps(points []f32, steps u32, c gx.Color)
children.name: draw_cubic_bezier_in_steps

comments.text:  draw_ellipse_empty draws the outline of an ellipse.
 `x`,`y` defines the center of the ellipse.
 `rw` defines the *width* radius of the ellipse.
 `rh` defines the *height* radius of the ellipse.
 `c` is the color of the outline.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_ellipse_empty(x f32, y f32, rw f32, rh f32, c gx.Color)
children.name: draw_ellipse_empty

comments.text:  draw_ellipse_filled draws an opaque ellipse.
 `x`,`y` defines the center of the ellipse.
 `rw` defines the *width* radius of the ellipse.
 `rh` defines the *height* radius of the ellipse.
 `c` is the fill color.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_ellipse_filled(x f32, y f32, rw f32, rh f32, c gx.Color)
children.name: draw_ellipse_filled

comments.text:  draw_image draws the provided image onto the screen.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_image(x f32, y f32, width f32, height f32, img_ &Image)
children.name: draw_image

comments.text:  draw_image_3d draws an image with a z depth

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_image_3d(x f32, y f32, z f32, width f32, height f32, img_ &Image)
children.name: draw_image_3d

comments.text:  draw_image_by_id draws an image by its id

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_image_by_id(x f32, y f32, width f32, height f32, id int)
children.name: draw_image_by_id

comments.text:  draw_image_flipped draws the provided image flipped horizontally (use `draw_image_with_config` to flip vertically)

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_image_flipped(x f32, y f32, width f32, height f32, img_ &Image)
children.name: draw_image_flipped

comments.text:  Draw part of an image using uv coordinates
 img_rect is the size and position (in pixels on screen) of the displayed rectangle (ie the draw_image args)
 part_rect is the size and position (in absolute pixels in the image) of the wanted part
 eg. On a 600*600 context, to display only the first 400*400 pixels of a 2000*2000 image
 on the entire context surface, call :
 draw_image_part(Rect{0, 0, 600, 600}, Rect{0, 0, 400, 400}, img)

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_image_part(img_rect Rect, part_rect Rect, img_ &Image)
children.name: draw_image_part

comments.text:  draw_image_with_config takes in a config that details how the
 provided image should be drawn onto the screen

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_image_with_config(config DrawImageConfig)
children.name: draw_image_with_config

comments.text:  draw_line draws a line between the points `x,y` and `x2,y2` in color `c`.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_line(x f32, y f32, x2 f32, y2 f32, c gx.Color)
children.name: draw_line

comments.text:  draw_line_with_config draws a line between the points `x,y` and `x2,y2` using `PenConfig`.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_line_with_config(x f32, y f32, x2 f32, y2 f32, config PenConfig)
children.name: draw_line_with_config

comments.text:  draw_pixel draws one pixel on the screen.
 NOTE calling this function frequently is very *inefficient*,
 for drawing shapes it's recommended to draw whole primitives with
 functions like `draw_rect_empty` or `draw_triangle_empty` etc.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_pixel(x f32, y f32, c gx.Color)
children.name: draw_pixel

comments.text:  draw_pixels draws pixels from an array of points [x, y, x2, y2, etc...]
 NOTE calling this function frequently is very *inefficient*,
 for drawing shapes it's recommended to draw whole primitives with
 functions like `draw_rect_empty` or `draw_triangle_empty` etc.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_pixels(points []f32, c gx.Color)
children.name: draw_pixels

comments.text:  draw_poly_empty draws the outline of a polygon, given an array of points, and a color.
 NOTE that the points must be given in clockwise winding order.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_poly_empty(points []f32, c gx.Color)
children.name: draw_poly_empty

comments.text:  draw_polygon_filled draws a filled polygon.
 `x`,`y` defines the center of the polygon.
 `size` defines the size of the polygon.
 `edges` defines number of edges in the polygon.
 `rotation` defines rotation of the polygon.
 `c` is the fill color.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_polygon_filled(x f32, y f32, size f32, edges int, rotation f32, c gx.Color)
children.name: draw_polygon_filled

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_rect(p DrawRectParams)
children.name: draw_rect

comments.text:  draw_rect_empty draws the outline of a rectangle.
 `x`,`y` is the top-left corner of the rectangle.
 `w` is the width, `h` is the height and `c` is the color of the outline.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_rect_empty(x f32, y f32, w f32, h f32, c gx.Color)
children.name: draw_rect_empty

comments.text:  draw_rect_filled draws a filled rectangle.
 `x`,`y` is the top-left corner of the rectangle.
 `w` is the width, `h` is the height and `c` is the color of the fill.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_rect_filled(x f32, y f32, w f32, h f32, c gx.Color)
children.name: draw_rect_filled

comments.text:  draw_rounded_rect_empty draws the outline of a rounded rectangle with a thickness of 1 px.
 `x`,`y` is the top-left corner of the rectangle.
 `w` is the width, `h` is the height.
 `radius` is the radius of the corner-rounding in pixels.
 `c` is the color of the outline.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_rounded_rect_empty(x f32, y f32, w f32, h f32, radius f32, c gx.Color)
children.name: draw_rounded_rect_empty

comments.text:  draw_rounded_rect_filled draws a filled rounded rectangle.
 `x`,`y` is the top-left corner of the rectangle.
 `w` is the width, `h` is the height .
 `radius` is the radius of the corner-rounding in pixels.
 `c` is the color of the filled.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_rounded_rect_filled(x f32, y f32, w f32, h f32, radius f32, c gx.Color)
children.name: draw_rounded_rect_filled

comments.text:  draw_slice_empty draws the outline of a circle slice/pie

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_slice_empty(x f32, y f32, radius f32, start_angle f32, end_angle f32, segments int, c gx.Color)
children.name: draw_slice_empty

comments.text:  draw_slice_filled draws a filled circle slice/pie
 `x`,`y` defines the end point of the slice (center of the circle that the slice is part of).
 `radius` defines the radius ("length") of the slice.
 `start_angle` is the angle in radians at which the slice starts.
 `end_angle` is the angle in radians at which the slice ends.
 `segments` affects how smooth/round the slice is.
 `c` is the fill color.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_slice_filled(x f32, y f32, radius f32, start_angle f32, end_angle f32, segments int, c gx.Color)
children.name: draw_slice_filled

comments.text:  draw_square_empty draws the outline of a square.
 `x`,`y` is the top-left corner of the square.
 `s` is the length of each side of the square.
 `c` is the color of the outline.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_square_empty(x f32, y f32, s f32, c gx.Color)
children.name: draw_square_empty

comments.text:  draw_square_filled draws a filled square.
 `x`,`y` is the top-left corner of the square.
 `s` is the length of each side of the square.
 `c` is the fill color.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_square_filled(x f32, y f32, s f32, c gx.Color)
children.name: draw_square_filled

comments.text:  draw_text draws the string in `text_` starting at top-left position `x`,`y`.
 Text settings can be provided with `cfg`.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_text(x int, y int, text_ string, cfg gx.TextCfg)
children.name: draw_text

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_text2(p DrawTextParams)
children.name: draw_text2

comments.text:  draw_text draws the string in `text_` starting at top-left position `x`,`y` using
 default text settings.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_text_def(x int, y int, text string)
children.name: draw_text_def

comments.text:  default draw_text (draw_text_def but without set_text_cfg)

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_text_default(x int, y int, text string)
children.name: draw_text_default

comments.text:  draw_triangle_empty draws the outline of a triangle.
 `x`,`y` defines the first point
 `x2`,`y2` defines the second point
 `x3`,`y3` defines the third point
 `c` is the color of the outline.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_triangle_empty(x f32, y f32, x2 f32, y2 f32, x3 f32, y3 f32, c gx.Color)
children.name: draw_triangle_empty

comments.text:  draw_triangle_filled draws a filled triangle.
 `x`,`y` defines the first point
 `x2`,`y2` defines the second point
 `x3`,`y3` defines the third point
 `c` is the color of the outline.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) draw_triangle_filled(x f32, y f32, x2 f32, y2 f32, x3 f32, y3 f32, c gx.Color)
children.name: draw_triangle_filled

comments.text:  end finishes all the drawing for the context ctx.
 All accumulated draw calls before ctx.end(), will be done in a separate Sokol pass.
 Note: each Sokol pass, has a limit on the number of draw calls, that can be done in it.
 Once that limit is reached, the whole pass will not draw anything, which can be frustrating.
 To overcome this limitation, you may use *several passes*, when you want to make thousands
 of draw calls (for example, if you need to draw thousands of circles/rectangles/sprites etc),
 where each pass will render just a limited amount of primitives.
 In the context of the gg module (without dropping to using sgl and gfx directly), it means,
 that you will need a new pair of ctx.begin() and ctx.end() calls, surrounding all the draw
 calls, that should be done in each pass.
 The default ctx.end() is equivalent to ctx.end(how:.clear). It will erase the existing
 rendered content with the background color, before drawing anything else.
 You can call ctx.end(how:.passthru) for a pass, that *will not* erase the previously
 rendered content in the context.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) end(options EndOptions)
children.name: end

comments.text:  get_cached_image_by_idx returns a cached `Image` identified by `image_idx`.
 See also: cache_image
 See also: remove_cached_image_by_idx

children.content: fn (mut ctx Context) get_cached_image_by_idx(image_idx int) &Image
children.name: get_cached_image_by_idx

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) has_text_style() bool
children.name: has_text_style

comments.text:  new_streaming_image returns a cached `image_idx` of a special image, that
 can be updated *each frame* by calling:  gg.update_pixel_data(image_idx, buf)
 ... where buf is a pointer to the actual pixel data for the image.
 Note: you still need to call app.gg.draw_image after that, to actually draw it.

children.content: fn (mut ctx Context) new_streaming_image(w int, h int, channels int, sicfg StreamingImageConfig) int
children.name: new_streaming_image

comments.text:  quit closes the context window and exits the event loop for it

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) quit()
children.name: quit

comments.text:  record_frame records the current frame to a file.
 record_frame acts according to settings specified in `gg.recorder_settings`.

children.content: fn (mut ctx Context) record_frame()
children.name: record_frame

comments.text:  refresh_ui requests a complete re-draw of the window contents.

children.content: fn (mut ctx Context) refresh_ui()
children.name: refresh_ui

comments.text:  remove_cached_image_by_idx removes an `Image` identified by `image_idx` from the
 image cache.
 See also: cache_image
 See also: get_cached_image_by_idx

children.content: fn (mut ctx Context) remove_cached_image_by_idx(image_idx int)
children.name: remove_cached_image_by_idx

comments.text:  Resize the context's Window

children.content: fn (mut ctx Context) resize(width int, height int)
children.name: resize

comments.text:  run starts the main loop of the context.

children.content: fn (mut ctx Context) run()
children.name: run

comments.text:  Stuff for ui from now for screenshot (that would be interesting for gg if screenshot is implemented also for gg)
 required for ui.DrawDevice interface (with &gg.Context as an instance)

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) scissor_rect(x int, y int, w int, h int)
children.name: scissor_rect

comments.text:  set_bg_color sets the color of the window background to `c`.

children.content: fn (mut ctx Context) set_bg_color(c gx.Color)
children.name: set_bg_color

comments.text:  set_text_cfg sets the current text configuration

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) set_text_cfg(cfg gx.TextCfg)
children.name: set_text_cfg

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) set_text_style(font_name string, font_path string, size int, color gx.Color, align int, vertical_align int)
children.name: set_text_style

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) show_fps()
children.name: show_fps

comments.text:  text_height returns the height of the `string` `s` in pixels.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) text_height(s string) int
children.name: text_height

comments.text:  text_size returns the width and height of the `string` `s` in pixels.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) text_size(s string) (int, int)
children.name: text_size

comments.text:  text_width returns the width of the `string` `s` in pixels.

children.content: fn (ctx &Context) text_width(s string) int
children.name: text_width

comments.text:  update_pixel_data is a helper for working with image streams (i.e. images,
 that are updated dynamically by the CPU on each frame)

children.content: fn (mut ctx Context) update_pixel_data(cached_image_idx int, buf &u8)
children.name: update_pixel_data

comments.text:  window_size returns the current dimensions of the window.

children.content: fn (ctx Context) window_size() Size
children.name: window_size

contents.content:
struct Context {
mut:
	render_text bool = true
	// a cache with all images created by the user. used for sokol image init and to save space
	// (so that the user can store image ids, not entire Image objects)
	image_cache   []Image
	needs_refresh bool = true
	ticks         int // for ui mode only
pub:
	native_rendering bool
pub mut:
	scale       f32 = 1.0 // will get set to 2.0 for retina, will remain 1.0 for normal
	width       int
	height      int
	clear_pass  gfx.PassAction
	window      sapp.Desc
	pipeline    &PipelineContainer = unsafe { nil }
	config      Config
	user_data   voidptr
	ft          &FT = unsafe { nil }
	font_inited bool
	ui_mode     bool // do not redraw everything 60 times/second, but only when the user requests
	frame       u64  // the current frame counted from the start of the application; always increasing
	//
	mbtn_mask     u8
	mouse_buttons MouseButtons // typed version of mbtn_mask; easier to use for user programs
	mouse_pos_x   int
	mouse_pos_y   int
	mouse_dx      int
	mouse_dy      int
	scroll_x      int
	scroll_y      int
	//
	key_modifiers     Modifier // the current key modifiers
	key_repeat        bool     // whether the pressed key was an autorepeated one
	pressed_keys      [key_code_max]bool // an array representing all currently pressed keys
	pressed_keys_edge [key_code_max]bool // true when the previous state of pressed_keys,
	// *before* the current event was different
	fps FPSConfig
}
contents.name: Context
PaintStyle

contents.content:
struct DrawRectParams {
	x          f32
	y          f32
	w          f32
	h          f32
	color      gx.Color   = gx.black
	style      PaintStyle = .fill
	is_rounded bool
	radius     f32
}
contents.name: DrawRectParams
MouseButton

comments.text:  Note: unlike the MouseButton enum from above,
 the [flag]-ed enum here can have combined states,
 representing several pressed buttons at once.

contents.name: MouseButtons
Modifier
PenLineType

contents.content:
enum KeyCode {
	invalid       = 0
	space         = 32
	apostrophe    = 39 //'
	comma         = 44 //,
	minus         = 45 //-
	period        = 46 //.
	slash         = 47 ///
	_0            = 48
	_1            = 49
	_2            = 50
	_3            = 51
	_4            = 52
	_5            = 53
	_6            = 54
	_7            = 55
	_8            = 56
	_9            = 57
	semicolon     = 59 //;
	equal         = 61 //=
	a             = 65
	b             = 66
	c             = 67
	d             = 68
	e             = 69
	f             = 70
	g             = 71
	h             = 72
	i             = 73
	j             = 74
	k             = 75
	l             = 76
	m             = 77
	n             = 78
	o             = 79
	p             = 80
	q             = 81
	r             = 82
	s             = 83
	t             = 84
	u             = 85
	v             = 86
	w             = 87
	x             = 88
	y             = 89
	z             = 90
	left_bracket  = 91 //[
	backslash     = 92 //\
	right_bracket = 93 //]
	grave_accent  = 96 //`
	world_1       = 161 // non-us #1
	world_2       = 162 // non-us #2
	escape        = 256
	enter         = 257
	tab           = 258
	backspace     = 259
	insert        = 260
	delete        = 261
	right         = 262
	left          = 263
	down          = 264
	up            = 265
	page_up       = 266
	page_down     = 267
	home          = 268
	end           = 269
	caps_lock     = 280

struct Event {
pub mut:
	frame_count        u64
	typ                sapp.EventType
	key_code           KeyCode
	char_code          u32
	key_repeat         bool
	modifiers          u32
	mouse_button       MouseButton
	mouse_x            f32
	mouse_y            f32
	mouse_dx           f32
	mouse_dy           f32
	scroll_x           f32
	scroll_y           f32
	num_touches        int
	touches            [8]TouchPoint
	window_width       int
	window_height      int
	framebuffer_width  int
	framebuffer_height int
}
contents.name: Event
Config
PipelineContainer

comments.text: ---- public methods
 start creates a new context and runs it right away.
 It is a convenient way to start short/throwaway gg based prototypes,
 that do not need to keep and update their own state, like simple
 animations/visualisations that depend only on the time, or the ctx.frame counter.
 Use gg.new_context() for more complex ones.

contents.content: fn start(cfg Config)
contents.name: start

comments.text:  new_context returns an initialized `Context` allocated on the heap.

contents.content: fn new_context(cfg Config) &Context
contents.name: new_context

comments.text:  Image holds the fields and data needed to
 represent a bitmap/pixel based image in memory.
 init_sokol_image initializes this `Image` for use with the
 sokol graphical backend system.

children.content: fn (mut img Image) init_sokol_image() &Image
children.name: init_sokol_image

comments.text:  update_pixel_data updates the sokol specific pixel data associated
 with this `Image`.

children.content: fn (mut img Image) update_pixel_data(buf &u8)
children.name: update_pixel_data

contents.content:
struct Image {
pub mut:
	id          int
	width       int
	height      int
	nr_channels int
	ok          bool
	data        voidptr
	ext         string
	simg_ok     bool
	simg        gfx.Image
	ssmp        gfx.Sampler
	path        string
}
contents.name: Image

contents.content:
struct StreamingImageConfig {
	pixel_format gfx.PixelFormat = .rgba8
	wrap_u       gfx.Wrap        = .clamp_to_edge
	wrap_v       gfx.Wrap        = .clamp_to_edge
	min_filter   gfx.Filter      = .linear
	mag_filter   gfx.Filter      = .linear
	num_mipmaps  int = 1
	num_slices   int = 1
}
contents.name: StreamingImageConfig

comments.text:  DrawImageConfig struct defines the various options
 that can be used to draw an image onto the screen

contents.content:
struct DrawImageConfig {
pub:
	flip_x    bool
	flip_y    bool
	img       &Image = unsafe { nil }
	img_id    int
	img_rect  Rect // defines the size and position on image when rendering to the screen
	part_rect Rect // defines the size and position of part of the image to use when rendering
	rotate    int  // amount to rotate the image in degrees
	z         f32
	color     gx.Color    = gx.white
	effect    ImageEffect = .alpha
}
contents.name: DrawImageConfig
ImageEffect

comments.text:  Rect represents a rectangular shape in `gg`.

contents.content:
struct Rect {
pub:
	x      f32
	y      f32
	width  f32
	height f32
}
contents.name: Rect

contents.content: type Color = gx.Color
contents.name: Color

contents.content:
struct SSRecorderSettings {
pub mut:
	stop_at_frame     i64 = -1
	screenshot_frames []u64
	screenshot_folder string
	screenshot_prefix string
}
contents.name: SSRecorderSettings

contents.content:
struct DrawTextParams {
	x    int
	y    int
	text string

	color          Color = gx.black
	size           int   = 16
	align          gx.HorizontalAlign = .left
	vertical_align gx.VerticalAlign   = .top
	max_width      int
	family         string
	bold           bool
	mono           bool
	italic         bool
}
contents.name: DrawTextParams
